Answer: I believe that the solution did not come from your subconscious, but from the combination of your subconscious and your conscious. I find that for difficult problems, the first step is to let the conscious mind work at it very hard, analyze it in every possible way. Only after the conscious mind is exhausted is it time to hand it over. Then ‚Äúsit back‚Äù and relax. Maybe go to sleep. Do something unrelated. Exercise is great. Take a hike. Suddenly the answer will pop into your head.When this happens to me, I knew I was not getting there consciously, but I also believe that without all that consciI believe that the solution did not come from your subconscious, but from the combination of your subconscious and your conscious. I find that for difficult problems, the first step is to let the conscious mind work at it very hard, analyze it in every possible way. Only after the conscious mind is exhausted is it time to hand it over. Then ‚Äúsit back‚Äù and relax. Maybe go to sleep. Do something unrelated. Exercise is great. Take a hike. Suddenly the answer will pop into your head.When this happens to me, I knew I was not getting there consciously, but I also believe that without all that conscious effort, my subconscious would not have succeeded either. The conscious mind is disciplined (or can be), and that discipline is usually essential. But it gets hung up and repeats the same approach. The subconscious mind is more freely moving, and connects ideas from different arenas.I employ this approach very consciously. Some people mistakenly think that they need to beat a problem into the ground. I can tell lots of stories about how walking away from the problem was essential.Yet I feel that a third stage is equally important. The idea has to be turned back to the conscious mind to check it, to work out the numbers, to test its validity. Those three stages are essential for the most challenging problems.
